SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.
Content: In paragraph 1 of Passage 1, the word “medium” refers to

A.Choice: a style of speaking.

B.Choice: a method of communication.

C.Choice: a device that delighted people.

D.Choice: a machine that only worked some of the time.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: According to Passage 1, what do Sarnoff's early job experiences suggest about his later achievements?

A.Choice: His practice of saving the money he earned proved useful when he moved to another city.

B.Choice: His employers valued his creativity and supported his desire to expand the use of radio.

C.Choice: His hard work and ability to learn quickly enabled him to advance in business.

D.Choice: His family urged him to work in different fields to find what he could do well.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to Passage 2, why were movies important to the development of television?

A.Choice: Movies linked images and sound for the first time.

B.Choice: Movies attracted audiences by focusing on jazz musicians.

C.Choice: Movies showed that television would help families relax at home.

D.Choice: Movies proved that television would be a tool for government leaders.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.
Content: In Passage 2, which evidence BEST supports the claim that Philo T. Farnsworth invented television?

A.Choice: He had an independent spirit.

B.Choice: He met with Vladimir Zworykin.

C.Choice: He only worked on electronic devices.

D.Choice: He won the case in court against RCA.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Which sentence BEST states a central idea of Passage 2?

A.Choice: Television sales slowed because of the start of World War II.

B.Choice: Television was first developed by someone outside of RCA.

C.Choice: Inventors had to overcome challenges to create television.

D.Choice: Laboratories cooperated to make television possible.

Content: Which choice provides the BEST evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: “Scientists had worked for years on mechanical devices that never held much promise.”

B.Choice: “Farnsworth was a 21-year-old self-taught genius from a farm in Utah.”

C.Choice: “The corporation lost the case and had to pay Farnsworth fees.”

D.Choice: “By 1955, half of all U.S. households had television sets.”

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Integrate information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words to develop a coherent understanding of a topic or issue.
Content: What idea in Passage 2 does the time line in Passage 1 support?

A.Choice: The opening of the World's Fair in 1939 was a key event in television history.

B.Choice: RCA struggled in the 1930s to get credit for inventing the television.

C.Choice: Sarnoff used a boxing match to introduce radio to many people.

D.Choice: Sarnoff used radios before they became available to the public.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast one author's presentation of events with that of another (e.g., a memoir written by and a biography on the same person).
Content: How do Passage 1 and Passage 2 present information about Sarnoff?

A.Choice: Passage 1 considers his life story, and Passage 2 considers his work history.

B.Choice: Passage 1 describes his early inventions, and Passage 2 describes his later inventions.

C.Choice: Passage 1 explains the challenges he faced, and Passage 2 highlights the successes he had.

D.Choice: Passage 1 focuses on his contributions to radio, and Passage 2 focuses on his role in television.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which detail from the passage BEST shows that space junk affects life on Earth?

A.Choice: NASA keeps creating more space junk.

B.Choice: NASA knows that space junk is found in a low orbit.

C.Choice: Space junk is created when satellites are destroyed.

D.Choice: Space junk can interfere with communication satellites.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.
Content: As used in paragraph 2, the word “fragments” refers to

A.Choice: tools for fixing something that was damaged.

B.Choice: parts of something that was whole.

C.Choice: rules that people ignored.

D.Choice: errors that people made.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Integrate information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words to develop a coherent understanding of a topic or issue.
Content: How does the diagram support the information in the passage?

A.Choice: It explains which type of debris is the most dangerous.

B.Choice: It suggests how long debris remains in orbit around Earth.

C.Choice: It represents the composition of human-made debris orbiting Earth.

D.Choice: It demonstrates which types of human-made debris are the largest.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Content: What is the MOST LIKELY reason the author includes paragraph 4 in the passage?

A.Choice: to show that the issue of space junk has been difficult to solve

B.Choice: to provide the steps necessary for getting rid of space junk

C.Choice: to give the history of space junk from beginning to end

D.Choice: to describe which areas are most affected by space junk

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.
Content: How does the author support the claim that the amount of space junk around Earth will likely increase?

A.Choice: by reporting that people enjoy space travel and research

B.Choice: by including data about the number of expected launches

C.Choice: by explaining how difficult it is to design and build a spacecraft

D.Choice: by describing the training that will soon be needed for engineers

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Which sentence BEST describes the author's point of view on space junk?

A.Choice: NASA is responsible for solving the problem of space junk.

B.Choice: Space junk is a crisis that scientists cannot solve.

C.Choice: We must address the problem of space junk to make space safer.

D.Choice: Various countries are at fault for creating space junk.S

Content: Which choice provides the BEST evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: “Scientists have a few ideas on how to remove space debris.”

B.Choice: “The European Space Agency is working on a harpoon system that can grab debris.”

C.Choice: “International agreements to ban satellite-destroying tests can help reduce further debris.”

D.Choice: “A more permanent solution is needed.”

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: What does paragraph 5 in Passage 1 reveal about the brothers' relationship?

A.Choice: Farid wants to make Zaki laugh.

B.Choice: Farid enjoys Zaki's brotherly admiration.

C.Choice: Zaki is jealous of Farid's reputation for finding pearls.

D.Choice: Zaki's feelings toward Farid cause Zaki to practice more.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: In Passage 1, why is Zaki's grandfather a good choice to watch and advise Zaki?

A.Choice: He is Zaki's closest relative.

B.Choice: He is an experienced diver.

C.Choice: Farid asked him to help Zaki.

D.Choice: The village men expect him to help.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 18 of Passage 1, what is the effect of the tone created by Zaki's choice of the words “Now” and “Let us go”?

A.Choice: It emphasizes how serious Zaki is about winning the contest.

B.Choice: It reveals why Zaki's grandfather is helping Zaki.

C.Choice: It casts doubt on Zaki's ability to achieve success.

D.Choice: It makes the reader question Zaki's motives.

SubTopics: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
Content: How would paragraphs 21 and 22 in Passage 1 be different if they were told from Farid's point of view?

A.Choice: The reader would understand how Farid is able to hold his breath for so long.

B.Choice: The reader would know what Farid was going to say when he surfaced.

C.Choice: The reader would know what Farid was planning to do if he won the contest.

D.Choice: The reader would understand why the smile was fading from Farid's face.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 12 of Passage 2, what does the phrase “the perfume of the flowers” reveal about Clytie?

A.Choice: She thinks the flowers smell wonderful.

B.Choice: She thinks the flowers smell strange.

C.Choice: She thinks the flowers resemble her own gardens.

D.Choice: She thinks that she is dreaming.

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
In Passage 2, how has Clytie changed by the end of the story?

A.Choice: She has become the new ruler of the sky.

B.Choice: She has found happiness on land in a new form.

C.Choice: She has learned to appreciate her underwater home.

D.Choice: She has become bitter and upset about her situation.

Content: Which choice provides the BEST evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: “With all these treasures Clytie should have been happy.”

B.Choice: “After this, she came every day, wishing more and more to be like the great kind king.”

C.Choice: “She leaned out over the sea and knew that she had her wish.”

D.Choice: “Her yellow hair had become golden petals.”

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres (e.g., stories and poems; historical novels and fantasy stories) in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics.
Content: Which of the following BEST describes how Zaki and Clytie each feel about the sea?

A.Choice: Zaki views the sea as ugly, while Clytie views it as beautiful.

B.Choice: Zaki views the sea as a threat, while Clytie views it as peaceful.

C.Choice: Zaki views the sea as his home, while Clytie views it as a strange place.

D.Choice: Zaki views the sea as an opportunity, while Clytie views it as restrictive.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Content: How should the underlined word in sentence 1 be changed to maintain the style of the passage?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: a whole lot

C.Choice: a great deal

D.Choice: an excessive amount

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Content: How should the underlined word in sentence 10 be changed?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: these artists

C.Choice: their artwork

D.Choice: the experiences

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Content: The writer is deciding whether sentence 12 helps develop the topic of the second paragraph. Should the writer keep sentence 12?

A.Choice: Yes, because it offers important details about the materials used to make installation art.

B.Choice: Yes, because it provides an example of installation art that needs to be experienced.

C.Choice: No, because it does not assist in the readers' understanding of outdoor installation art.

D.Choice: No, because it does not show how installation art can communicate popular stories.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Content: Which change makes the underlined portion of sentence 13 more precise?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: Unlike a traditional sculpture

C.Choice: Unusual for this sort of thing

D.Choice: Contrary to the normal kind of sculpture

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Content: How should the underlined word in sentence 14 be changed?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: her

C.Choice: our

D.Choice: their

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Which choice would be the BEST to add as a concluding sentence for the passage?

A.Choice: Even though installation art is all around, many people still do not know what it is.

B.Choice: In an art gallery or a public park, installation art invites people not just to look at it, but to explore it.

C.Choice: Installation art is also special because it is often only on display for a short period of time.

D.Choice: Sometimes it seems as though installation art can have many different interpretations.

Content: Which choice provides the BEST evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: “lights switched on and off every five seconds”

B.Choice: “One of the most important things to know”

C.Choice: “that viewers can walk through like hallways”

D.Choice: “imagine interacting with the setting”

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Content: Which pronoun should replace the underlined word in sentence 2?

A.Choice: his

B.Choice: its

C.Choice: their

D.Choice: them

SubTopics: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.
Content: :ibox:THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS.
Which sentence would be BEST to add after sentence 3 to introduce the claim of the argument?

A.Choice: Community gardens exist in all different types of communities.

B.Choice: It can be difficult to find a garden plot that does not have strict rules.

C.Choice: However, the benefits of community gardens far outweigh any difficulties they create.

D.Choice: Sometimes, gardeners have to find creative ways to pay for the rental costs and fees.

Content: Which detail from the argument BEST supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “require users to share tools”

B.Choice: “growing fresh produce costs less”

C.Choice: “sometimes sell some of the food they grow”

D.Choice: “some people work the same garden plot for many years”

SubTopics: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.
Content: The writer wants to include a detail after sentence 5 to support the statement made in sentence 5. Which choice is BEST?

A.Choice: Many people say that they like eating fresh fruits and vegetables, but these foods can be hard to find.

B.Choice: Some experts suggest adding cut-up fruit to cereal in the morning and eating raw vegetables with a low-fat dip.

C.Choice: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention say that only 1 in 10 North Americans eats the recommended number of fruits and vegetables per day.

D.Choice: A Michigan State University study found that families with garden plots were 3.5 times more likely to eat at least 5 servings of fruits and vegetables per day.

SubTopics: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.
Content: The writer is considering adding the phrase “a Yale University professor who studied the relationship between people's health and the environment” after the name Steven Kellert in sentence 9. Should the writer make this addition?

A.Choice: Yes, because it shows that the information about children and nature comes from a trusted source.

B.Choice: Yes, because it explains why Kellert's research is different from other research in the field.

C.Choice: No, because the information about children and nature is not important in the argument.

D.Choice: No, because it focuses attention on Kellert's workplace rather than the research itself.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Which TWO choices would best replace the underlined word in sentence 11? Select TWO answers.

A.Choice: cuts

B.Choice: declines

C.Choice: decreases

D.Choice: reduces

SubTopics: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence.
Content: How should the underlined word in sentence 15 be changed to provide the best transition to the ideas that follow?

A.Choice: As it happens

B.Choice: For example

C.Choice: In the process

D.Choice: In the meantime

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.
Content: Now read the writing task and draft a response. As you write, think about what makes writing successful.
problems/NMG6E/media/33a.jpg

:box:You have read about an artist, Georgia O'Keeffe, and about other artists in New Mexico who make art out of natural or human-made objects they find. Your class is putting together a magazine, and you decide to write a story for it. Write a story about a character, real or imaginary, who finds an object and makes it into something else. Use details from what you read, along with your own ideas and experiences, to write your story.

:ibox:Today you will be writing a narrative text. When you write a narrative, you

• recount a real or imaginary series of events in an engaging way.
• think about how your story can affect your audience through humor, sympathy, or other emotions.
• put events in an order that makes sense.
• use specific details to make the events and characters interesting.

After you have read the passages, and before you begin writing, think about

• who your narrative will be about.
• what events you want your narrative to include.
• when and where the events in your narrative happen.
• why the person or people in your narrative think and act as they do.

Now write your response in the space provided.
